11:13 am
PM11:14am

Analysis of a potential merger of Vodafone and Idea Cellular
Our analysis of a potential merger of Vodafone India with Idea Cellular reveals that such a mega deal would change the industry order. A Vodafone-Idea combined entity would have 43% revenue market share vs the 33% of Bharti Airtel currently and 13% for Reliance Jio by FY19CL. A deal could boost the merged entity’s Ebitda by 25-30% led by savings in network and SG&A costs and lower net debt to Ebitda to 3.3x The potential merger would also hit Bharti Infratel’s Ebitda by ~7% due to shutdown of the overlapping sites. A deal would also pave the way for a backdoor listing of Vodafone India but regulatory approvals and spectrum caps are the key unknowns.

PM11:14am

Possibility of significant boost to Idea-Vodafone combined positioning
q With a merger, Vodafone-Idea combined would have a 43% revenue market share. q Bharti Airtel currently leads the sector with 33% revenue market share, and we
forecast a 13% share for Reliance Jio by FY19
q The merger would help Vodafone India improve its positioning in the mass-market,
while Idea Cellular would gain from Vodafone’s strength in metro circles.
q Not only would the combined entity become the industry leader but also a strong competitor in the data market with 3G spectrum across India and the highest 4G
spectrum in the 1800MHz band, enabling sufficient capacity spectrum.

PM11:14am

Sorry for the formatting

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Challenges: Regulatory approvals, spectrum sale and Indus’s stake
q India telecom M&A norms require the combined entity’s revenue and subscriber market shares to be below 50% and spectrum holdings to be below specified caps.
q Our analysis reveals the Vodafone-Idea combined entity would hit revenue market share, subscriber market share and spectrum caps in five of the 22 circles.
q The merged entity would get a year to align with revenue and subscriber market share caps but it would have to part sell/surrender spectrum to be below the cap.
q The new entity would have to pay Rs57bn to liberalise its administered spectrum
which would be offset if the merged entity can sell excess spectrum worth Rs54bn. q With Vodafone-Idea owning 53% of Indus Towers and Bharti Airtel 42%, raising an
issue of control, the merger may compel Idea to sell its towers/Indus holding.

PM11:14am

But enough of that

PM11:14am

It's for real now

11:14 am
PM11:15am

And it's really complicated

BE11:15am

Goldman can talk us through the detail, if you want.

PM11:15am

Sure

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Aside from potential synergies, Indian consolidation would likely alleviate competitive concerns over Vodafone India, which we believe are a key reason in explaining recent underperformance (c.10% underperformance vs. SXKP over the last three months). Vodafone/Idea combination: we estimate potential synergies could be worth c.6-12p/share to Vodafone, assuming VOD takes a 50% share of synergies using a range of 4%-8% of the combined opex/capex base in line with similar transactions. We note the two assets are of a similar size. Market repair benefit: as highlighted in our recent Vodafone upgrade note, we see potential Indian in-market consolidation as supporting overall market repair benefit assuming competition from Jio is more benign medium to long term. Our previously published scenarios suggest a return to top-line growth for Vodafone could be worth up to an additional c.10p/share.

BE11:16am

For more details on potential Indian consolidation and our broader thesis see our recent upgrade note Self-help raises confidence in growth outlook; up to Buy. At our unchanged 12-month ROIC-based price of 260p/$38 ADR, VOD would trade on c.7% CY18E FCF yield. Our price target, implying 28% upside, includes c.£0.10/share of potential consolidation benefits based on our synergy capture analysis of VOD merging its businesses with cable players in the UK and Germany. Key downside risks to our view and price target include sustained intense Indian competition, regulation, capital discipline and FX.

BE11:16am

(@Upaswellasdown: I can't see why that'd be the case.)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And Caz.

BE11:17am

Key highlights from the statement are: (1) any potential merger would be consummated through the issuance of new shares in Idea to Vodafone, (2) the deal would see Vodafone deconsolidate India suggesting they may sell down some of their equity holding, (3) Vodafone would retain its 42% stake in Indus, which could then potentially be sold off separately. We have written extensively on the merits of such a potential merger in recent research (most recently in All eyes on India), arguing that such a transaction could unlock $9bn in potential deal synergies and offer Vodafone an elegant route to deconsolidating India, thereby helping focus attention back onto a rebounding European equity story. If confirmed, we believe this deal would remove a major overhang, and support a significant re-rating of Vodafone’s share price.

BE11:18am

Speculation over a Vodafone-Idea merger has gained momentum
over recent weeks with several media reports (see the Economic Times of India) suggesting a potential deal was nearing. Adding to such speculation, Bharti’s Chairman Sunil Mittal spoke at Davos noting that a Vodafone-Idea merger would be a “perfect match” and we have also seen Idea postpone its Q3 results which were due to be released on January 23rd. Interestingly, such M&A hopes have seen local Indian stocks Bharti and Idea rally strongly (+15% and +19% respectively since Reliance Jio’s 5th September new entrant launch) whereas in stark contrast, Vodafone shares have suffered with investors squarely focused on ongoing Indian downgrades (-14% since 5th September). In fact, at the time of writing, Idea is now +26% today alone whilst Bharti is +8%.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Skipping a bit ..

BE11:19am

Substantial synergy potential: In our Indian M&A report earlier this month we argued that a Vodafone-Idea merger could offer substantial synergies. Looking at the major in-market mobile-mobile mergers that have taken place in Europe over recent years, we note the targeted synergies, in each, were very similar, equating to 8-10% of combined opex and 18-20% of combined capex. Applying this benchmark to a Vodafone-Idea deal would imply $8-9bn of potential synergies. However we believe the true savings could be much higher, with one key area of incremental synergy being network costs. The rationale for this is that Indian Telcos currently have to compensate for their scarce spectrum footprints through building dense network grids. This entails substantial opex (tower leases, energy costs) and capex (installing and maintaining equipment) costs. A combined Vodafone-Idea would have 264k towers, which is 70% higher than the 154k possessed by Bharti. Based on disclosure by Bharti Infratel, we estimate that leasing a site costs around INR408k pa ($6k). Assuming that a merged Vodafone/Idea would target a grid 10% larger than that of Bharti would still allow the new entity to cede 95k sites at a potential annual saving of INR35bn. This would imply an NPV of around INR330bn, which even by itself would represent ~60% of the total (gross) synergies implied by benchmarking to the Germany mobile merger.

BE11:20am

(@Upaswellasdown: but what would Malone get from a Vodafone merger that he wouldn't get from, for example, buying the UK network outright?)

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Anyway, that's that.

PM11:20am

Blimey, this really is complex

PM11:20am

Hence the muted share price reaction here, i guess

The American consulting engineer playing a key role in Britain’s new High Speed Two rail route has approached its UK competitor WS Atkins about a possible $4 billion merger.

CH2M is believed to have contacted its listed British rival, with whom it often partners on projects, at the end of last year to explore whether a tie-up could work. It is believed the approach was made at a senior level, though it is unclear how far talks developed.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Anyway, Numis upgrade.

Hill & Smith Holdings PLC (HILS:LSE): Last: 1,169, up 34 (+3.00%), High: 1,169, Low: 1,144, Volume: 39.71k
BE11:44am

Hill & Smith shares have drifted over recent months. Indeed the performance has diverged from other 'Trump stocks' since the Presidential election; H&S +9.5%, Ashtead +33%, Vesuvius +34% and the Engineering sector +18%. The PE rating (17x 2017) is now a discount to the sector, if high by historic levels. With Brexit also looking less of an issue and currency benefits we see upside risk to numbers (with further potential from bolt-ons as usual). A 5% upgrade to numbers and sector PE of 18x suggests 1280p target price and hence we put the shares back on a positive rating (Add from Hold).

11:45 am
BE11:45am

(The phrase "Trump stocks" feels more awkward than it did last week. There's a risk that it's increasingly coming to mean Academi, G4S and Aegis Defence Services rather than the makers of pipes.)

BE11:46am

UK. Post Brexit we took a slightly cautious view on the UK business, in particular the housing related activities. The group’s Birtley subdivision of businesses manufacture doors, lintels, plasterers accessories and associated building metalwork structures and is highly exposed to the housing sector. The business has sales of c. £40m with margins close to 10%. The predicted fall off in housing starts post Brexit is now replaced by more positive expectations for 5% growth suggesting the business should now make positive progress in 2017.

BE11:46am

North America. The US business performed well in 2016 assisted by the second full year from the new Memphis galvanizing plant. Obama’s five year $305bn highways bill was passed in 2015 but the spending benefits only started to come through in H2 2016 suggesting that there is more to come for H&S from this avenue even before Trump’s infrastructure splurge is enacted. At present we have broadly flat underlying numbers for galvanizing assuming some UK softness offsetting US growth and French recovery. If the UK continues as expected and additional US infrastructure comes through this could prove a touch conservative. In addition the Zoneguard temporary road barrier business appears to be gaining traction at just the right time.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

BE11:46am

TOROTRAK - Exclusive first drive: Torotrak's V-Charge technology TRK.L - ENP Newswire

11:49 am
PM11:49am

This was on Reuters

PM11:49am

Being the first journalist to test drive the only example of a new piece of technology still in development always concentrates the mind. Doing so in wet and windy weather battering rural roads close to England's North Sea coast, brings an added dimension to the experience.

But that was how Torotrak demonstrated to Automotive Engineering the potential of its new, CVT-controlled V-Charge pressure charger-a mechanical, gearless, fully variable pressure charger driven by a conventional pulley. It allows compressor speed to vary independent of engine speed. It's designed to provide low-end torque and tackle the effects of turbo-lag on downsized gasoline engines. (See http://articles.sae.org/12401/; also SAE Technical Paper http://papers.sae.org/2015-01-1971/).

Fitted to a 1.0-L Ford Focus as a technology demonstrator (Torotrak is partnering with Ford on this project), it is currently being shown to industry engineers and senior executives across Europe.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Flybe’s December quarter update showed an encouraging improvement in the unit revenue trend. Q3 revenue per seat rose by 0.2% YoY, compared with a 6.9% decrease in H1. The comparative was weak, having been impacted by the Paris attacks, but the confirmation of the expected improvement is reassuring. We make minimal changes to our estimates, with the trading environment still uncertain. Our recommendation remains BUY with a 50p target price.

BE11:56am

Key figures

Seat capacity 3.1m (+13% YoY), Passengers 2.1m (+10% YoY), Load factor 67.2% (-1.7pts YoY).

Passenger revenue £146.3m (+14% YoY), Total revenue £160.8m (+18% YoY).

Passenger yield +2.8% YoY, Passenger revenue per seat +0.2% YoY.

Cost per seat -3.4% YoY, Cost per seat (ex-fuel, constant currency) +1.6%.

BE11:56am

Revenue per seat improving against a soft comparative

The highlight of the trading update was the unit revenue performance. Revenue per seat improved by 0.2% YoY. This represented a clear improvement over the H1 performance (6.9% fall) and the forward booking data available at the last update in November (down 9%).

We had expected an improvement. Q3 saw Flybe start to lap the Paris attacks of November 2015, which depressed activity in the comparative period. Also, the trend over recent quarters has been for the revenue per seat outturn to be materially better than that indicated by the initial forward bookings. Nonetheless, it is reassuring to have the improving trend confirmed.

The quarter also provided the first evidence of Flybe's capacity growth starting to slow, albeit only marginally to 12.7% from 13.5% in H1. Flybe’s fleet peaks this year, with the delivery of the final aircraft under the NAC transaction due in the final quarter. The group has given notice to lessors that it will be returning six aircraft at the scheduled end of their leases in the second half of the next financial year (March 2018E).

The cost performance was mixed. Total cost per seat improved by 3.4%, which was helped by lower fuel costs, implying margin expansion compared with flat revenue per seat. However, underlying unit costs rose by 1.6% on additional contract flying for SAS (an arithmetic distortion since this is profitable extra flying that adds to costs but not to scheduled seat capacity), increased operational disruption costs from bad weather in December and higher EU261 passenger compensation costs.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

The improving revenue per seat trend points to potential upside risk to estimates if extrapolated. However, we are reluctant to do so given the uncertain outlook, and Q4 is the seasonally weakest quarter for the industry.

Q4 is currently 38% booked, in line with this time last year. At present, forward bookings point to a 1% decrease in yield and revenue per seat, on a 13% increase in capacity and 11% increase in passenger revenue. However, management has highlighted uncertain consumer confidence and poor weather contributing to a slow start to the quarter.

Flybe has extended its jet fuel and US dollar hedges to the end of the next financial year, in line with its established policy. We estimate it has covered more than 80% of its requirements for 2018E. Although post-hedge jet fuel prices should show a further material improvement next year, this will be partially offset by the adverse movement in the exchange rate. At the current spot prices, FX would remain a headwind in 2019E, while fuel prices would stabilise in US dollar terms.

BE11:56am

Flybe’s update, along with the commentary in easyJet’s recent trading statement, highlights the still-challenging trading conditions in the European airline industry. However, there are tentative signs of stabilisation against weak comparatives. For Flybe, the recovery opportunity remains in getting its capacity growth back under control, with the current rapid growth rate the side effect of the resolution of legacy problems. The confirmation that six aircraft will be returned to lessors in the second half of the next financial year is welcome in that context. Slower capacity growth should also improve average route maturity, and hence it should be supportive for unit revenues. Exiting expensive aircraft should also improve unit costs. However, in the meantime they remain a drag on earnings, along with the difficult demand environment.

A March 2017E EV/EBITDAR of 5.8x (2018E: 5.4x) puts Flybe's rating in between the higher rated low cost carriers and the lower rated network airlines. This appears appropriate, but with upside potential if Flybe can demonstrate further progress. Our recommendation remains BUY with a 50p target price.

BE11:57am

I don't have to say they're shop broker, right? They have their name on a damn plane, of course they're shop broker.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Numis as well.

BE11:58am

Flybe says that and that as it passed the anniversary of the Paris attacks and management actions took effect, “seat capacity growth started to slow, passenger yield increased and the decline in revenue per seat slowed". This led to an encouraging 0.2% increase in passenger revenue per seat in Q3, after a -6.9% in H1. It has been a slow start to Q4, which will also be impacted by the timing of Easter. Therefore, whilst we have increased conviction, our forecasts are unchanged.

BE11:58am

(Thanks @otter. That Photoshop training's really paying off.)
